sn22.54:1.2: These terms are defined in detail in Bu Pc 11:2.1.1. Bījajāta are not “kinds of seeds” but “that which is born from a seed” i.e. “plants” (bhūtagāmo nāma pañca bījajātāni).
sn22.54:1.4: “Plants propagated from roots” (mūlabīja, literally “that which has a root for a seed”) include ginger and turmeric; from “stems” (khandhabīja) the Bodhi tree and the banyan tree; from “cuttings” (aggabīja) basil and hemp; from “joints” (phalubīja) sugarcane and bamboo; and from “regular seeds” (bījabīja), grains and vegetables.
sn22.54:1.5: Sukhasayita is sometimes understood as “well planted”, but how can it be planted when there is no soil? It is explained by the commentary as “well-kept”, literally “well laid by”.
sn22.54:1.11: Pali uses the same word viññāṇaṭṭhiti for the seven “planes of consciousness” (realms of rebirth, AN 7.44, DN 15:33.1) as for the four “grounds for consciousness”, the other four aggregates on which consciousness is based.
sn22.54:1.13: See too AN 3.76:2.3: “deeds are the field, consciousness is the seed, and craving is the moisture”.
sn22.54:4.2: For the “establishment of consciousness”, namely the rebirth of consciousness in a new life, see too SN 12.64.
